Suspect in Shooting of 2 Jewish Men in LA Pleads Not Guilty

LOS ANGELES (AP) — A man who allegedly shot and wounded two Jewish men as they left synagogues in Los Angeles last month pleaded not guilty Thursday to federal hate crimes, authorities said.

Jaime Tran, the suspect in the case, has a history of antisemitic and threatening conduct, according to documents filed by the FBI. The shootings on Feb. 15 and Feb. 16, which targeted men wearing identifying Jewish clothing such as black coats and head coverings, brought fear into LA's Jewish community.

In response to the incident, Los Angeles Mayor Karen Bass addressed community members and state and local law enforcement officials in a town hall on anti-Semitic violence at YULA Boys High School in Los Angeles on Feb. 20. The event provided an opportunity for officials to express their support for the Jewish community and discuss ways to combat hate crimes.

Tran appeared in federal court Thursday and entered a not-guilty plea to charges of hate crimes. Kate Corrigan, one of Tran's attorneys, said she expects to receive discovery-hearing evidence within the coming days as she prepares his defense.

“We'll be looking at the overall scenario in this case and addressing the charges,” she said Thursday.

According to an affidavit filed by the FBI, Tran told law enforcement that he looked online for a “kosher market” and decided to shoot someone nearby. The FBI's review of emails, text messages, and other reports also revealed Tran's previous history of antisemitic behavior.

In 2022, Tran allegedly emailed former classmates with insulting language about Jewish people and repeatedly threatened a Jewish former classmate. He sent messages like “Someone is going to kill you, Jew” and “I want you dead, Jew,” according to the affidavit.

Tran's not guilty plea comes as the nation grapples with a wave of hate crimes against Asian, Black, Jewish and LGBTQ communities. The Associated Press and other news outlets have reported a sharp increase in such incidents since the start of the COVID-19 pandemic.

Los Angeles city officials have committed to combating hate crimes and have implemented several initiatives aimed at preventing them. In August 2022, LA's City Council formed a Task Force on Anti-Semitism to address and combat hate crimes against the Jewish community.

The FBI is continuing its investigation into Tran's alleged hate crimes, and the case is ongoing.
